content.description:
The face to the left of The Reaper. Climb overhanging rock to a very small dihedral. The second part of the climb is full of Jugs (hence the name), but the protection options are very low.

Right-most route at Reaper Buttress.
Standard rack.

Start up the arete / face to the right of Mr. Toady's Dihedral. Clip a high first bolt then continue up and fire the crux just before clipping the second bolt. Be gratful for the high first bolt, then continue up to the chains. Short but fierce.

Right of Mr. Toady's.
2 bolts. Bolted anchor.

This climb is awesome. A bit short, but definitely worth trying. It is graded a bit old-school (as with most climbs in gatineau park, beware of the ''+'') 
  
 Start on broken ground and gain the base of the pink dihedral. Jam and stem up this until the corner crack dissipates into nothingness and you have to use face holds, maybe the arete out left if you so desire. Put in your last piece of gear before the crack disappears (0.5 WC helium size) climb up over it and commit to the reachy / dynamic crux (depends on how tall you are). Really bad holds await, but don't let go, and clip a bolt. You think it's over now, don't you? Oh no. You still have to clip the chains. Be creative with what you have (not much), and feel around for hidden holds (key) and finally clip the chains.

The left-most route on the reaper buttress. Obvious pink granite dihedral.
Standard rack. Ditch the big stuff. Basically hand size for the bottom and figer size for the upper part. 1 bolt (spins...) Bolted anchor.

Climb up an overhanging wall and then up to a very very thin crack. The second bolt is extremely high. Bolted for thrills.

Middle of Reaper Buttress.
2 bolts. Long runout to the 2nd. Bolted anchors.
Reaper Buttress is a nice little crag with quality granite and a good mix of routes.
